text: If you do the hard path and it doesn't work, actually you still win because you've now done something hard. You've probably worked with smart people. You've learned something along the way that is valuable. I meet lots of job seekers. I go, what are you doing to try to find a job? Are you really learning anything from sending out 10 resumes a day? Why don't you look at the API Docs and build something? Even if you don't get a job at Shopify, you've learned something.
speaker: Farhan Thawar
context: Lenny asks Farhan to explain his philosophy of choosing the harder path when deciding between options. Farhan explains that when you take the easy route and it fails, you learn nothing, but when you take the hard path and it fails, you still gain valuable skills and experience. He uses job searching as an example - instead of just sending out resumes, candidates should build something with a company's APIs to demonstrate skills and learn in the process.
text_ko: 어려운 길을 택해서 잘 안 되더라도 사실 이긴 거예요. 왜냐하면 어려운 걸 해봤고, 아마 똑똑한 사람들과 함께 일해봤을 거고, 그 과정에서 가치 있는 걸 배웠기 때문이에요. 구직자들을 많이 만나는데 저는 항상 묻죠, 취업을 위해 지금 뭘 하고 계세요? 하루에 이력서 10통씩 보내는 걸로 진짜 배우는 게 있나요? 왜 API 문서(API Docs)를 보고 직접 뭔가 만들어보지 않아요? 설령 쇼피파이(Shopify)에 못 가더라도 분명 배운 게 있을 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你选择了困难的路，就算最后没成功，其实你也是赢家，因为你已经做了一件有挑战性的事情。你可能和聪明人一起共事过，一路上肯定学到了有价值的东西。我见过很多找工作的人，我就问他们，你现在在做什么来找工作？每天投10份简历你真的能学到什么吗？为什么不去看看API文档，自己做点东西出来？就算最后没进Shopify，你也学到东西了啊。
text_es: Si tomas el camino difícil y no funciona, en realidad igual ganas porque ya hiciste algo complicado. Probablemente trabajaste con gente inteligente. Aprendiste algo en el proceso que tiene valor. Conozco muchas personas que buscan trabajo. Les pregunto, ¿qué estás haciendo para conseguir trabajo? ¿De verdad estás aprendiendo algo mandando 10 currículums al día? ¿Por qué no mejor revisas la documentación de APIs y construyes algo? Aunque no consigas trabajo en Shopify, ya aprendiste algo.
key_sentence: You win by taking the hard path and learning valuable lessons along the way.

text: I have been in many situations with many sharp people who have said to me, that's the stupidest fucking question I've ever heard. My goal there is not to annoy the person, but it's to understand the content.
speaker: Farhan Thawar
context: Lenny asks about Farhan's quote that looking stupid in public is his superpower. Farhan explains that he's comfortable asking questions that others might consider dumb because his priority is understanding the content rather than protecting his image. He shares that even successful business people have harshly criticized his questions, but he persists because learning is more important than appearing smart.
text_ko: 저는 여러 상황에서 예리한 분들이 저에게 “이건 내가 들어본 것 중에 가장 어처구니없는 질문이야”라고 말하는 걸 많이 겪었어요. 제 목표는 그 사람을 짜증나게 하려는 게 아니라, 내용을 제대로 이해하려는 거예요.
text_zh: 我遇到过很多聪明人，他们会对我说，这是我听过的最蠢的问题了。但我的目的不是要惹他们生气，而是想真正搞懂这个事儿。
text_es: He estado en muchas situaciones con gente muy lista que me ha dicho: "esa es la pregunta más estúpida que he escuchado en mi puta vida". Mi objetivo ahí no es joder a la persona, sino entender realmente el contenido.
key_sentence: Sharp people often dismiss questions, but understanding content is the goal.

text: They're mostly different people, but they're similar in one thing is that they haven't... they have an irrational view of what the world should look like over the next decade or so. They're very long-term thinkers, very rational in that they'll look and say, 'Hey, in 10, 15, 20, 25 years, this is what the world's going to look like.' And I'm not good at seeing that vision, but I'm good at trying to move towards that vision 1% a week.
speaker: Farhan Thawar
context: Lenny points out that Farhan has worked for a different billionaire each decade of his career and asks what connects these successful leaders. Farhan explains that while these leaders are different people, they share the ability to envision how the world will look decades in the future. He recognizes that his strength is execution - moving toward their vision incrementally - rather than having the visionary ability himself.
text_ko: 대부분 서로 다른 사람들이지만, 한 가지 닮은 점이 있어요. 앞으로 10년쯤 동안 세상이 어떻게 돼야 한다고 좀 비현실적인 관점을 가지고 있다는 거예요. 그 사람들은 굉장히 장기적 사고를 하는 사람들(long-term thinkers)이라서, 10년, 15년, 20년, 25년 뒤에는 세상이 이렇게 될 거라고 이성적으로 말해요. 저는 그런 비전(vision)을 한눈에 보는 건 잘 못하지만, 대신 그 비전을 향해 매주 1%씩이라도 움직이려고 해요.
text_zh: 这些人大部分都不一样，但有一个共同点，就是他们对未来十年左右世界应该是什么样子，都有一种"不理性"的看法。他们都是很有长远眼光的人，很理性地会说："嘿，十年、十五年、二十年、二十五年后，世界就会是这个样子。"我看不到那种远景，但我擅长朝着那个远景每周前进1%。
text_es: Son personas muy diferentes en su mayoría, pero tienen algo en común: tienen una visión... digamos, irracional de cómo debería verse el mundo en la próxima década. Son pensadores a muy largo plazo, muy racionales en el sentido de que analizan y dicen: "Oye, en 10, 15, 20, 25 años, así va a ser el mundo." Y yo no soy bueno para ver esa visión, pero sí soy bueno tratando de avanzar hacia esa visión un 1% cada semana.
key_sentence: They have an irrational view of the future but move towards that vision 1% a week.

text: It is the most underutilized management tool in engineering, bar none. It is just not used as much as it could be. So pair programming, for those who don't know, it's two people on one computer. The throughput limiter is not hands-on keyboard. The limiter is where is the good elegant solution? How do we think through the problem and build the right solution for the problem at hand?
speaker: Farhan Thawar
context: Lenny asks why Farhan is such a big advocate for pair programming, since it seems counterintuitive to have two engineers working on one computer. Farhan argues that pair programming is incredibly underused in engineering management. He explains that the bottleneck in software development isn't typing speed but finding the right solution to problems - and two people working together are much better at this than one person alone.
text_ko: 엔지니어링에서 이보다 덜 활용되는 관리 도구는 없어요, 정말로. 그냥 충분히 쓰이고 있지 않아요. 페어 프로그래밍(pair programming)은, 모르는 분들을 위해 말하면 두 사람이 한 대의 컴퓨터에서 함께 일하는 방식이에요. 처리량 병목(throughput limiter)은 키보드를 직접 두드리는 사람(hands-on keyboard)이 아니에요. 진짜 제약은 어디에 좋은 우아한 해결책(elegant solution)이 있느냐예요. 문제를 어떻게 생각해서 당면한 문제에 맞는 올바른 해결책을 만드는지가 중요해요.
text_zh: 这绝对是工程管理中最被低估的工具，没有之一。真的是远远没有发挥出它应有的作用。结对编程(pair programming)，不了解的朋友我解释一下，就是两个人用一台电脑写代码。其实效率的瓶颈根本不在于谁在敲键盘，真正的瓶颈是怎么找到那个优雅的解决方案，怎么把问题想透彻，然后针对手头的问题做出最合适的方案。
text_es: Es la herramienta de gestión más subutilizada en ingeniería, sin lugar a dudas. Simplemente no se usa tanto como debería. Entonces, la programación en pareja (pair programming), para quienes no la conocen, son dos personas trabajando en una sola computadora. El cuello de botella no está en quién tiene las manos en el teclado. La limitante está en encontrar esa solución elegante y buena. ¿Cómo pensamos el problema y construimos la solución correcta para lo que tenemos entre manos?
key_sentence: Pair programming is the most underutilized management tool in engineering, bar none.

text: Everyone says, 'Oh yeah, work hard and do more hours when you're young, whatever.' I'm like, 'What if you just did more per minute?' Like quickly get through things. I think there's another unintuitive fact is that people who are really good can actually output high-quality collateral quickly.
speaker: Farhan Thawar
context: Lenny asks about creating intensity in organizations, specifically Farhan's philosophy of expending more energy per hour rather than working longer hours. Farhan challenges the conventional wisdom of working more hours when young, suggesting instead that people should focus on accomplishing more within the same timeframe. He points out that highly skilled people can produce quality work faster, not just work longer.
text_ko: 사람들은 다들 '젊을 때 열심히 일하고 근무 시간 더 늘려라'고 하죠. 저는 '그럼 분당 더 많이 해보면 어때요?'라고 해요. 일을 빠르게 처리하는 거죠. 또 의외인 건, 진짜 잘하는 사람들은 고품질의 영업·마케팅 자료(collateral)를 빠르게 만들어낼 수 있다는 거예요.
text_zh: 大家都说"趁年轻多加班多干活什么的"，我就想，你为什么不试试提高每分钟的效率呢？就是快速把事情搞定。还有个违反常理的现象，真正厉害的人其实能又快又好地产出高质量的材料。
text_es: Todo el mundo dice, "Ah sí, trabaja duro y echa más horas cuando eres joven, lo que sea." Yo pienso, "¿Y si simplemente rindieras más por minuto?" O sea, despachar las cosas rápido. Creo que hay otra cosa contraintuitiva y es que la gente que es realmente buena sí puede producir material de alta calidad rápidamente.
key_sentence: Focus on doing more per minute to produce high-quality collateral quickly.

text: We can always almost find a million-plus lines of code to delete, which is insane. But at the same time, I applaud the teams for going after the cruft and the code base. And everything gets easier, right? Code loads faster. It's easier to understand.
speaker: Farhan Thawar
context: Lenny asks about Shopify's initiative to delete code and simplify their codebase. Farhan explains that they have a Delete Code Club and regularly find millions of lines of code that can be removed during hack days. He sees this as beneficial because removing unnecessary code makes everything faster and easier to understand, though he acknowledges it might seem counterintuitive to celebrate deleting work.
text_ko: 우리는 거의 항상 백만 줄이 넘는 코드를 지워도 될 부분을 찾아낼 수 있어요. 정말 말도 안 돼요. 하지만 동시에 그런 쓸데없는 코드(cruft)와 코드베이스(code base)를 정리하러 나선 팀들은 정말 칭찬받아 마땅해요. 그러면 모든 게 더 쉬워져요. 코드 로딩도 빨라지고 이해하기도 쉬워져요.
text_zh: 我们几乎总能找到上百万行可以删掉的代码，这简直太疯狂了。不过同时我也得给团队点个赞，他们敢于清理那些冗余代码和代码库。然后你知道吗，一切都变得更容易了，对吧？代码跑得更快，也更好理解了。
text_es: Siempre podemos encontrar más de un millón de líneas de código para eliminar, lo cual es una locura. Pero a la vez, aplaudo a los equipos por ir tras toda esa basura (cruft) y limpiar la base de código. Y todo se vuelve más fácil, ¿no? El código carga más rápido. Es más fácil de entender.
key_sentence: Teams are going after the cruft, making the code base easier to understand.
